title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdos Problem #560: Size Ramsey Numbers**

This problem asks for the size Ramsey number R_hat(K_{n,n}) - the minimum number of EDGES (not vertices) in a graph H such that any 2-coloring of H's edges contains a monochromatic K_{n,n}.

**Status:** OPEN - exact value unknown, bounds established

**Known Bounds:**
(1/60)n^2*2^n < R_hat(K_{n,n}) < (3/2)n^3*2^n

The gap between bounds is O(n).
mathContext: Size Ramsey numbers measure edge-complexity of Ramsey phenomena, in contrast to classical Ramsey numbers which count vertices.

title: Edge Coloring
content:
**EdgeColoring:**

A 2-coloring of edges assigns each edge a color (True or False, representing red/blue).

**Definition:**
```lean
def EdgeColoring (G : SimpleGraph V) := G.edgeSet -> Bool
```

This is the fundamental object for Ramsey-type problems.

title: Complete Bipartite Graph K_{n,n}
content:
**completeBipartiteGraph:**

K_{n,n} has two disjoint sets of n vertices each, with an edge between every vertex in one set and every vertex in the other.

**Definition:** Uses Sum types (Fin n + Fin n) for vertices:
```lean
def completeBipartiteGraph (n : N) : SimpleGraph (Fin n + Fin n) where
  Adj v w := match v, w with
    | Sum.inl _, Sum.inr _ => True
    | Sum.inr _, Sum.inl _ => True
    | _, _ => False
```

**Edge count:** K_{n,n} has n^2 edges.
mathContext: Complete bipartite graphs are fundamental in graph theory and have rich Ramsey-theoretic properties.

title: Monochromatic Copy and Size Ramsey
content:
**HasMonochromaticCopy and sizeRamseyNumber:**

A monochromatic copy of G in H under coloring c is an embedding of G into H where all mapped edges have the same color.

**Size Ramsey Number:** R_hat(G) is the minimum edge count m such that:
- There exists H with m edges
- Every 2-coloring of H contains a monochromatic G

This is fundamentally different from classical Ramsey numbers which minimize vertices.
mathContext: The size Ramsey number can be much smaller than C(R(G),2), the edges in the complete graph on R(G) vertices.

title: Erdos-Rousseau Lower Bound (1993)
content:
**erdos_rousseau_lower_bound:**

For n >= 6, R_hat(K_{n,n}) > (1/60)*n^2*2^n.

**Statement:**
```lean
axiom erdos_rousseau_lower_bound (n : N) (hn : n >= 6) :
    (R_hat(K[n,n]) : R) > (1 / 60) * n^2 * 2^n
```

This was proved using probabilistic counting arguments.
mathContext: The lower bound shows that even edge-minimal Ramsey graphs for K_{n,n} must have exponentially many edges with n^2 polynomial factor.

title: Upper Bound (EFRS 1978)
content:
**upper_bound:**

R_hat(K_{n,n}) < (3/2)*n^3*2^n.

**Statement:**
```lean
axiom upper_bound (n : N) (hn : n >= 1) :
    (R_hat(K[n,n]) : R) < (3 / 2) * n^3 * 2^n
```

Proved independently by EFRS (1978) and Nesetril-Rodl (1978) using explicit constructions.
mathContext: The upper bound constructs specific graphs that force monochromatic K_{n,n} in any 2-coloring.

title: Combined Size Ramsey Bounds
content:
**size_ramsey_bounds:**

Combines both bounds into a single theorem for n >= 6:

(1/60)*n^2*2^n < R_hat(K_{n,n}) < (3/2)*n^3*2^n

The ratio of upper to lower bound is 90n, showing the gap is O(n).

title: Conlon-Fox-Wigderson Results (2023)
content:
**CFW General and Asymptotic Bounds:**

For s <= t:
- R_hat(K_{s,t}) >> s^{2-s/t} * t * 2^s
- When t >> s*log(s): R_hat(K_{s,t}) ~ s^2 * t * 2^s

These 2023 results give tight asymptotic bounds when t is large compared to s.

For the balanced case s = t = n, this suggests R_hat(K_{n,n}) ~ n^3 * 2^n.
mathContext: The CFW paper made significant progress on this 40+ year old problem, providing new techniques for both upper and lower bounds.

title: CFW Conjecture
content:
**cfw_conjecture:**

Conjectured: R_hat(K_{n,n}) = Theta(n^3 * 2^n).

This would mean:
- The upper bound (3/2)*n^3*2^n is tight up to constants
- The lower bound (1/60)*n^2*2^n can be improved by factor n
- The true order is n^3*2^n

This is the natural extension of asymptotic results to the balanced case.
mathContext: If true, this conjecture would resolve Problem #560 up to constant factors.

title: Basic Properties
content:
**Size Ramsey Properties:**

1. **Monotonicity:** G subgraph of G' implies R_hat(G) <= R_hat(G')

2. **Lower bound:** R_hat(G) >= |E(G)| (need at least as many edges)

3. **K_{1,1} case:** R_hat(K_{1,1}) = 1 (single edge)

4. **Path linear:** R_hat(P_n) = O(n) (linear in path length)

These basic properties establish the framework for size Ramsey theory.

title: Classical Ramsey Relation
mathContext: The relationship shows that size Ramsey numbers are always at most the edges in the complete graph on R(G) vertices, but can be much smaller.

title: Bounds Gap Analysis
content:
**bounds_gap:**

The ratio between upper and lower bounds:

(3/2)*n^3*2^n / ((1/60)*n^2*2^n) = 90*n

So the gap is O(n) - a linear factor of uncertainty remains.

**Implication:** If CFW conjecture is true (R_hat ~ n^3*2^n), then the lower bound can be improved by factor n while upper bound is optimal.

title: Main Results Summary
content:
**erdos_560_summary:**

Combines all main results for n >= 6:

1. **Lower bound:** (1/60)*n^2*2^n (Erdos-Rousseau 1993)
2. **Upper bound:** (3/2)*n^3*2^n (EFRS 1978)
3. **Monotonicity:** m <= n implies R_hat(K_{m,m}) <= R_hat(K_{n,n})

**Status:** OPEN - exact value unknown, O(n) gap between bounds

**Conjecture:** R_hat(K_{n,n}) = Theta(n^3*2^n) (CFW 2023)
